title: Discover the World’s First Earthquake Detector, Invented in China 2,000 Years Ago
content: The Renaissance did not, strictly speaking, occur in China. Yet it seems that the Middle Kingdom did have its Renaissance men, so to speak, and in much earlier times at that. We find one such illustrious figure in the Han dynasty of the first and second centuries: a statesman named Zhang Heng (78–139 AD), who […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: Luis Buñuel & Salvador Dalí’s Un Chien Andalou: The Short Surrealist Film That Revolutionized Cinema (1929)
content: Un Chien Andalou means “an Andalusian dog,” though the much-studied 1929 short film of that title contains no dogs at all, from Andalusia or anywhere else. In fact, it alludes to a Spanish expression about how the howling of an Andalusian signals that someone has died. And indeed, there is death in Un Chien Andalou, […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: Brazilian Musician Seu Jorge Performs 15 Iconic Bowie Songs in Portuguese to Mark the 10th Anniversary of Bowie’s Passing
content: In 2004, the Brazilian musician Seu Jorge recorded a series of Portuguese covers of David Bowie songs for Wes Anderson’s film The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou. The next year, he released a full album of 13 Bowie classics, and in 2016–2017, he even took the songs on tour. Now, in 2026, to mark the […]
creator: OC

title: A Brief Introduction to Buckminster Fuller and His Techno-Optimistic Ideas
content: Buckminster Fuller was, in many ways, a twenty-first century man: an achievement in itself, considering he was born in the nineteenth century and died in the twentieth. In fact, it may actually count as his defining achievement. For all the inventions presented as revolutionary that never really caught on — the Dymaxion house and car, […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: Watch the Evolution of Paris Unfold in a Timelapse Video, from 300 BCE to 2025
content: Though it’s easily forgotten in our age of air travel and instantaneous global communication, many a great city is located where it is because of a river. That holds true everywhere from London to Buenos Aires to Tokyo to New York — and even to Los Angeles, despite its own once-uncontrollable river having long since […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: Miles Davis Opens for Neil Young and “That  Sorry-Ass Cat” Steve Miller at The Fillmore East (1970)
content: The story, the many stories, of Miles Davis as an opening act for several rock bands in the 1970s makes for fascinating reading. Before he blew the Grateful Dead’s minds as their opening act at the Fillmore West in April 1970 (hear both bands’ sets here), Davis and his all-star Quintet—billed as an “Extra Added […]
creator: OC

title: How the “Netflix Movie” Turns Cinema into “Visual Muzak”
content: When Netflix launched around the turn of the millennium, it was received as a godsend by many American cinephiles, especially those who lived nowhere near diversely programmed revival houses or well-curated video stores. A quarter-century later, it’s safe to say that those days have come to an end. Not only does the streaming-only Netflix of […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: What Happens When Mortals Try to Drink Winston Churchill’s Daily Intake of Alcohol
content: I have taken more out of alcohol than alcohol has taken out of me. — Winston Churchill Winston Churchill had a reputation as a brilliant statesman and a prodigious drinker. The former prime minister imbibed throughout the day, every day.  He also burned through 10 daily cigars, and lived to the ripe old age of […]
creator: OC

title: MTV Rewind Lets You Revisit 40,000 Music Videos & Commercials from the Golden Age of MTV
content: MTV still exists. At least, it still exists in the United States, or in certain of that country’s markets, for the time being. A flurry of premature obituaries recently blew through the internet after the announcement that the network had shut down in other parts of the world, Europe included. But even there, some expressed […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: Discover Michelangelo’s First Painting, Created When He Was Only 12 or 13 Years Old
content: Think back, if you will, to the works of art you created at age twelve or thirteen. For many, perhaps most of us, our output at that stage of adolescence amounted to directionless doodles, chaotic comics, and a few unsteady-at-best school projects. But then, most of us didn’t grow up to be Michelangelo. In the […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: Download 435 High Resolution Images from John J. Audubon’s The Birds of America
content: In our experience, bird lovers fall into two general categories: Keenly observant cataloguers like John James Audubon … And those of us who cannot resist assigning anthropomorphic personalities and behaviors to the 435 stars of Audubon’s The Birds of America, a stunning collection of prints from life-size watercolors he produced between 1827 and 1838. Our suspicions have little […]
creator: OC

title: When Pianist Maria João Pires Prepared to Perform the Wrong Mozart Concerto, Then Recovered Miraculously
content: Imagine, if you will, taking a seat at the piano before a full house of 2,000 music lovers ready to hear Mozart’s Piano Concerto No. 20 in D minor — and, more importantly, on stage with an orchestra and conductor more than ready to play it. That would be difficult enough, but now imagine that […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: “Riders on the Storm” Performed by John Densmore, Robby Krieger and 20+ Musicians Around the World
content: Formed in 1965, the Doors burned hot until Jim Morrison died in 1971, and the band finally broke up in 1973. The group left behind more than a few fine songs—“Light My Fire,” “Break On Through (To the Other Side),” “L.A. Woman,” and “Roadhouse Blues,” to name a few. Above, the music collective Playing for […]
creator: OC

title: Stream 4,000+ Public Domain Movies on WikiFlix: Silent Classics, Academy Award-Winners, Hitchcock Films & More
content: Humanity was already enjoying motion pictures a century ago. But the ability to do so at home still lay a few decades in the future, and the ability to pull up a movie on demand through a streaming service much further still. Young people in the twenty-twenties may be unable to fathom how previous generations […]
creator: Colin Marshall

title: Cybernetic Attention: All Watched over by Machines We Learned to Watch
content: Before the attention economy consumed our lives, “pursuit tests” devised by the US military coupled man to machine with the aim of assessing focus under pressure. D. Graham Burnett explores these devices for evaluating aviators, finding a pre-history of the laboratory research that has relentlessly worked to slice and dice the attentional powers of human beings.

title: Flights of Fancy: The Nine Birds of Jacques de Fornazeris (1594)
content: Etchings of birds in a somewhat theatrical style.

title: A Prophet of the Weather: Lantern Slides by Clement Lindley Wragge (ca. 1900–22)
content: Slides from twenty years of lecturing about the workings of the universe and the fate of the soul.

title: Peter Kropotkin’s Memoirs of a Revolutionist (1899)
content: The memoirs of an aristocratic man revolutionised into an anarchist communist.

title: Happy Public Domain Day 2026!
content: Each January 1st is Public Domain Day, when a new crop of works have their copyrights expire and become free to share and reuse for any purpose. Here's our highlights for 2026.

title: Top 10 Most Read Pieces from 2025
content: From sublime spheres to hungry cats, a rundown of the ten most read of what we published this year.

title: A Thousand and One Nights in Italy: The Moorish Fantasias of Cesare Mattei and Ferdinando Panciatichi
content: In mid-19th century Italy, two eccentric aristocrats set forth on parallel projects: constructing ostentatious castles in a Moorish Revival style. Iván Moure Pazos tours the psychedelic chambers of Rochetta Mattei, optimised for electrohomeopathic healing, and Castello di Sammezzano, an immersive, orientalist fever dream.

title: Nature Morte: Chaïm Soutine’s Still Lifes (ca. 1920s)
content: Still lifes by the artist who seemed to bridge expressionism with the baroque.

title: Deceit and Disrobing: The Schefer Maqāmāt (BNF Arabe 5847, ca. 1237)
content: Illustrations of Abū Zayd and his adventures in double meaning.

title: Luke Howard’s Essay on the Modification of Clouds (1865)
content: First cloud taxonomer and a poem by Goethe.

title: The Launch of Our End-of-Year Fundraiser!
content: Our End-of-Year Fundraiser is launched, and the new postcards theme will be Attention.

title: “Quaint Dessert Dishes” in American Homes and Gardens (1911)
content: Bizarre sweet treats that resemble human and animal forms.

title: Henri Rivière’s Thirty-Six Views of the Eiffel Tower (1888–1902)
content: French lithographs of the Eiffel Tower and its environs, in the style of Japanese woodblock prints.

title: Art in Art: Cabinets of Curiosity and the Rise of the Gallery Painting
content: In the 17th century, emanating from Antwerp, a new genre of artwork came on the scene: paintings of paintings, works populated by a lush array of meta-images. From its origins in picturing private curiosity cabinets to its later use in documenting increasingly public collections, Thea Applebaum Licht charts the course of this alluring aesthetic tradition.

title: Too Computerised? Too Cold?: 1999 A.D. (1967)
content: A past vision of the future. Domestic utopia? Or sanitised hell?

title: New T-Shirts (Now in 100% Organic Cotton) and New Mugs in Our Shop!
content: Adorn your body and coffee in PDR goodness! We’ve just added 8 new T-shirts and 13 new mugs to our online shop.

title: Roma Lister, Aradia, and the Speculative Origins of a Witchcraft Revival
content: In 1899, Charles Godfrey Leland published Aradia, “the gospel of the witches”, containing a goddess-orientated creation and saviour narrative, purported to descend from an ancient, hermetic tradition of witchcraft in Italy. A. D. Manns explores this text via an enchanting conjecture: that the writer, medium, and witch Roma Lister played a pivotal role in the formation of both Aradia and, therefore

title: Last Order Dates for the Holiday Season - 2025
content: The recommended cut-off dates to order from our shop by to ensure delivery in time for Dec 25th.

title: Perverse, Grotesque, Sensuous, Inimitable: A Selection of Works by Aubrey Beardsley
content: Selections from an artist whose phantasmagoric works defined an era.

title: Animal Costumes from the 1862 Fairytale Ball of the Jung-München Artist’s Association
content: Photographs from a costume ball featuring fairytale fables.

title: PDR's Halloween Reader
content: This Halloween week, a devilish dive into our archives to unearth some supernatural treats...

title: “That’s Why We Become Witches”: Sylvia Townsend Warner’s Lolly Willowes (1926)
content: A novel about a woman who throws off the yoke of patriarchy to become a witch.

title: Hooked on Sonics: Experimenting with Sound in 19th-Century Popular Science
content: Of all the senses cultivated throughout the 19th century, it was the sense of hearing that experienced the most dramatic transformation, as the science of sound underwent rapid advancement. Lucas Thompson delves into a particular genre of popular acoustics primers aimed at children and amateurs alike, which reveal the pedagogical, ludic, and transcendental strivings of Victorian society.

title: A Treatise on the All-Healing Qualities of Earth Bathing (1790)
content: A medical tract on the health effects of burying oneself alive in mud.

title: Paramaribo and the Plantation: Gerrit Schouten’s Dioramas of Suriname (1810–30)
content: Dioramas avant la lettre that depict local life in Suriname.

title: The Nature of the Beast: Charles le Brun’s Human-Animal Hybrids (1806)
content: Illustrations of supposed physiognomic affinities between humans and animals.

title: The Adventures and Experiences of the First Slovak Novel
content: Partially banned upon publication and translated into English for the first time this year, *René, or: A Young Man’s Adventures and Experiences* (1783–85) found new readers in the communist era thanks to its critiques of feudalism, capitalism, and the Catholic Church. Dobrota Pucherová introduces us to this hybrid work, which mixes the bildungsroman with the philosophical novel, the romance, the a

title: Vertiginous Accounts: Travels in the Air (1871 edition)
content: Expedition accounts of aeronauts bravely venturing into the heavens on hot-air balloons.

title: Birth of the Pearl (1901)
content: A "living picture" film staging Botticelli’s *Birth of Venus* with a twist.

title: The End of the World as We (Didn’t) Know It: Now and Then #5
content: A Rapture that wasn’t, in 2025 and 1844.

title: The Shadow of Desire: Painting the Origins of Art (ca. 1625–1850)
content: Paintings illustrating Pliny the Elder’s account of the origins of art.

title: “You Think Me a Bold Cheat”: Mary Carleton, Counterfeit Princess
content: Accused of posing as foreign royalty to lure her young suitor into a bigamous marriage, Mary Carleton was the subject of dozens of pamphlets and broadsides published in the mid-17th century, including by Carleton herself. Investigating the fraudster’s life, Laura Kolb finds a self-fashioning figure who both influenced the emergence of the English novel and serves as a strange precursor to our mode

title: A Collection of Old English Customs, and Curious Bequests and Charities (1842)
content: A compilation of historical gifting traditions in England, with a focus on the peculiar.

title: Ivan Aivazovsky’s Miniature Seascapes (ca. 1887)
content: Identical photographs of the artist, each with a unique miniature painting at the centre.

title: The Cat’s Maew: Thai Treatise on Auspicious Felines (19th Century)
content: A manuscript that pairs illustrations of cats with poetic descriptions and notes on what mystical benefits their owners might hope to accrue.

title: Watching the World in a Dark Room: The Early Modern Camera Obscura
content: Centuries before photography froze the world into neat frames, scientists, poets, and artists streamed transient images into dark interior spaces with the help of a camera obscura. Julie Park explores the early modern fascination with this quasi-spiritual technology and the magic, melancholy, and dream-like experiences it produced.

title: Cannibal Modernity: Oswald de Andrade’s Manifesto Antropófago (1928)
content: A modernist manifesto inspired (controversially) by the Tupi people of Brazil.

title: Flowers of Fealty: Wilhelm Dilich’s Commemoration of the Christening of Elisabeth of Hesse (1598)
content: Commemorative manuscript featuring illustrations of pageants, costumes, and fireworks, later further illustrated by a separate artist, with floral motifs.

title: Breaking the Celestial Ceiling: Now and Then #4
content: Female astronomical first, in 2025 and 1787.

title: Through the Magnifying Glass: The Cheese Mites (1903)
content: A trick film in the peepshow vein, involving magnification and mites on a block of cheese.

title: Splitting Hairs: Chinese Immigrants, the Queue, and the Boundaries of Political Citizenship
content: As Chinese immigration to California accelerated across the 19th century, the hairstyle known as the queue — a long, braided pony tail — became the subject of white Americans’ fascination, disgust, and legal regulation. Sarah Gold McBride explores why hair served as an index of political subjecthood, and how the queue exposed cracks in American norms regarding gender, economy, and citizenship.

title: The Mowing-Devil (1678), or, the Earliest Known Depiction of a Crop Circle
content: A crop circle sighting tinged with Christian morality.

title: Perspiration, Bilocation, and Plagiarisation: “The Heat Wave” (1929)
content: Time travel and murder during a New York heat wave.

title: The “Private” Photographs of Bolette Berg and Marie Høeg (ca. 1895–1903)
content: Excerpts from a dazzling image collection, discovered in a Norwegian barn in the 1980s, that experiments with the presentation of gender.

title: Dancing Naked on the Head of a Pin: The Early History of Microphotography
content: In 1853, John Benjamin Dancer achieved a feat of seemingly impossible scale: he shrunk an image to the size of a sharpened pencil tip. Anika Burgess explores the invention of microphotography and its influence on erotic paraphernalia and military communications.

title: Trojan Pig: Tiny Cryptic #11
content: Eleventh instalment in our series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: The Language of Form: Lothar Schreyer’s Kreuzigung (1920)
content: The sole example of a Bauhaus workshop’s arcane theatrical scoring system, combining colours, words, and complex symbolic notation.

title: Strings Attached: Helen Haiman Joseph’s A Book of Marionettes (1920)
content: The first comprehensive history of marionette artistry in the English language.

title: Off with Their Heads: Illustrations of Blemmyes (ca. 1175–1724)
content: Depictions of the mythical creatures known as Blemmyes: humanoids whose eyes, nose, and mouth are embedded in their breast.

title: Imagining an Idle Countess: George Wightwick’s The Palace of Architecture
content: In 1840, British architect George Wightwick published a world history of architecture in the Romantic mode, inviting readers to enter a vast garden where Buddhist iconography rubs shoulders with Greek temples and Egyptian pyramids gaze upon Gothic cathedrals. His intended audience? Idle women. Matthew Mullane revisits this visionary but ultimately unpopular text, revealing the legacy of attempts t

title: Under Construction: Tiny Cryptic #10
content: Tenth instalment in our series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: Drawing on Tradition: Elena Izcue’s Peruvian Art in the School (1926)
content: A set of drawing workbooks embroiled in debates about the Indigenist aesthetic movement.

title: Charles Davy’s Conjectural Observations on the Origin and Progress of Alphabetic Writing (1772)
content: A series of conjectures about the primal scene of writing.

title: Bernard Sleigh’s Anciente Mappe of Fairyland (ca. 1920 edition)
content: A stunning six-foot-long map that joins the worlds of various myths and stories for the childhood adventurer.

title: The Old, Old, Very Old Man: Thomas Parr and the Longevity Trade
content: As the story goes, Old Tom Parr was relatively healthy for being 152 until a visit to noxious, polluted London in 1635 cut his long life short. Katherine Harvey investigates the early modern claims surrounding this supercentarian and the fraudulent longevity business that became his namesake in the 19th century.

title: Old Tricks: Tiny Cryptic #9
content: Ninth instalment in our series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: “The Great Enigma of Our Times”: Henry George’s Poverty and Progress (1881 edition)
content: A landmark work of social reform — proposing a land value tax — that helped usher in the Progressive Era.

title: In the Penal Colony: Now and Then #3
content: French overseas imprisonment, in 2025 and 1852.

title: Gilded Fish: Illustrations from Histoire naturelle des dorades de la Chine (1780)
content: Stunning illustrations from the first monograph on goldfish published in Europe.

title: Charles Butler’s The Feminine Monarchie, or the History of Bees (1634 edition)
content: The earliest full-length work of apiculture published in English, which popularised the discovery that bee colonies have queens instead of kings.

title: As Bright as a Feather: Ostriches, Home Dyeing, and the Global Plume Trade
content: In the 19th century, dyed ostrich feathers were haute couture, adorning the hats and boas of fashionistas on both sides of the Atlantic. Whitney Rakich examines the far-reaching ostrich industry through a peculiar do-it-yourself-style book: Alexander Paul’s The Practical Ostrich Feather Dyer (1888), a text interleaved with richly colored specimens.

title: Warburg’s Werewolf: An Anamnesis
content: Aby Warburg spent his life finding forms that could hold their own against the flow of time. All the while, as Kevin Dann explores, he was churning on the brink of madness with the sense that he himself was changing — into a terrifying animal. What kind of history would a werewolf write?

title: Mudpots and Fumaroles: Lithographs of Yellowstone’s Thermal Springs (1883)
content: Images gathered during a survey by Ferdinand V. Hayden, who was responsible for the designation of Yellowstone as a national park.

title: Feather Tickler: Tiny Cryptic #8
content: Eighth instalment in our series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: A Popeless Situation: Now and Then #2
content: Papal elections begin, in 2025 and 1268.

title: Tangled Dürer: The Six Knots (ca. before 1521)
content: Woodcut knots likely inspired by Mamluk decorative metalwork.

title: Nikolai Agnivtsev’s Little Screw (1925)
content: A 1925 Soviet Children’s book about a little screw whose importance is overlooked.

title: Confessional Boxes: Tiny Cryptic #7
content: Seventh instalment in our series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: “I Am Making the World My Confessor”: Mary MacLane, the Wild Woman from Butte
content: In 1902, a woman named Mary MacLane from Butte, Montana, became an international sensation after publishing a scandalous journal recording life at the age of 19. Rereading this often-forgotten debut, Hunter Dukes finds a voice that hungers for worldly experience, brims with bisexual longing, and rages against the injustices of youth.

title: Oskar Kokoschka, Hermine Moos, and the Alma Mahler Doll
content: Photographs of the life-size doll that Kokoschka had made to resemble his ex-lover Alma Mahler.

title: Photographs of the Samaritan Passover on Mount Gerizim (1917)
content: Images from a ritual practised for 127 generations.

title: Sea Monsters Unmasked and Sea Fables Explained by Henry Lee (1883)
content: Pamphlets on sea beasts produced for the International Fisheries Exhibition of 1883.

title: Modern Babylon: Ziggurat Skyscrapers and Hugh Ferriss’ Retrofuturism
content: In the early twentieth century, architects turned to a newly discovered past to craft novel visions of the future: the ancient history of Mesopotamia. Eva Miller traces how both the mythology of Babel and reconstructions of stepped-pyramid forms influenced skyscraper design, speculative cinema in the 1910s and 20s, and, above all else, the retrofuturist dreams of Hugh Ferriss, architectural deline

title: Zig-a-zig-ah: Tiny Cryptic #6
content: Sixth instalment in our series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: Sheet Mewsic: Moritz von Schwind’s Katzensymphonie (1868)
content: Sheet music whose notes have been replaced by rambunctious cats.

title: “The Form of a Demon and the Heart of a Person”: Kitagawa Utamaro’s Prints of Yamauba and Kintarō (ca. 1800)
content: Edo-era prints of a loving demon with adopted or biological son.

title: Uncommon Sense: Edward B. Foote’s Plain Home Talk (1896 edition)
content: An encyclopedic tome of health advice that unpicks the biases of its time.

title: Jack London, Jack Johnson, and the Fight of the Century
content: Held in Jim Crow–era Nevada on the 4th of July, the 1910 World Heavyweight Championship was slated to be a fight to remember. Moonlighting as a boxing journalist, novelist Jack London cheered on Jim Jeffries — ringside and on the page — as the “Great White Hope", a contender to take back the title from Jack Johnson, the first Black heavyweight champion. Andrew Rihn examines the contradictions of L

title: Boxing Clever: Tiny Cryptic #5
content: Fifth instalment in our series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: Bedded Bugs and Stung Beetles: The Cameraman’s Revenge (1912)
content: Perhaps the first work of puppet animation, featuring a cast composed of dead bugs.

title: Through a Glass Lushly: Michalina Janoszanka’s Reverse Paintings (ca. 1920s)
content: Overlooked kaleidoscopic images of nature painted directly onto glass.

title: The Mermaid “at Home!” (1809)
content: A grand, submarine entertainment in the form of a children’s book.

title: A Princely Ploy: Inside the Ruse of a French-Armenian Scammer
content: After proclaiming himself the direct descendant of a 12th-century Crusader king, the Armenian priest and educator Ambroise Calfa hit upon an ignoble scheme: grant knighthood to anyone willing to pay. Jennifer Manoukian recovers the cunning exploits of this forgotten 19th-century conman, whose initially honorable intentions quickly escalated into all-out fraud.

title: Ostrich Egg-Shell Cups of Mesopotamia and the Ostrich in Ancient and Modern Times (1926)
content: A cultural history of ostrich eggs and the birds that lay them.

title: Con Heir: Tiny Cryptic #4
content: Fourth instalment in our new series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: Master of Claude de France’s Book of Flower Studies (ca. 1510–1515)
content: Illuminations of European plants by an anonymous master.

title: José Guadalupe Posada’s Engravings of Unusual Births (ca. 1880–1910)
content: Engravings of unusual births by an artist best known for his joyous skeletons.

title: For He’s a Jolly Bad Fellow: Now and Then #1
content: Expulsion threat from the Royal Society, in 2025 and 1775.

title: The Emperor’s New Clothes: Fashion, Politics, and Identity in Mughal South Asia
content: The Mughal emperors in India faced a sartorial quandary: continue wearing their traditional Central Asian attire, or adopt the lighter cotton clothing of this warmer clime? Simran Agarwal considers the cultural, political, and theological implications of embracing Indic fashion, arguing that — by donning the clothing of their subjects — the Mughal emperors fashioned themselves anew.

title: The Drift of Things: David Goodman Croly’s Glimpses of the Future (1888)
content: A work of futurology intended to be read in 1888 and judged in 2000.

title: Sartorial Codes: Tiny Cryptic #3
content: Third instalment in our new series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: Gustatory Wisdom: Bruegel the Elder’s Twelve Proverbs (1558)
content: Proverbial scenes about human folly painted on serving plates.

title: What Is It Like to Be a Bass? Fish-Eye View Photography (1919–22)
content: Underwater photographs that try to capture the world from a fish’s perspective.

title: The Cat’s Meat Man: Feeding Felines in Victorian London
content: As cats evolved from feral ratters into beloved Victorian companions, a nascent pet-food economy arose on the carts of so-called “cat’s meat men”. Kathryn Hughes explores the life and times of these itinerant offal vendors, their intersection with a victim of Jack the Ripper, and a feast held in the meat men’s honor, chaired by none other than Louis Wain.

title: Paws for Thought: Tiny Cryptic #2
content: Second instalment in our new series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: Reality Iced: Robert J. Flaherty’s Nanook of the North (1922)
content: The first documentary film, the first ethnographic film, as well as the first art film?

title: Pied Beauty: Wari Tie-Dye Textiles (ca. 425–1100)
content: Patchwork, tie-dye textiles comprising some of the most extraordinary examples of Andean fabric art known to us.

title: George Baxter’s Print of Crystal Palace Dinosaurs (ca. 1854)
content: A Baxter process print of Hawkins’ re-creations of prehistoric life, which still stand today.

title: “Relaxations for the Impotent”: Ben Hecht’s Fantazius Mallare and the Contradictions of American Smut
content: J.-K. Huysmans pastiche? Formative influence on Allen Ginsberg’s Howl? Ben Hecht’s Fantazius Mallare (1922) is at turns obtuse, grotesque, and moralizing — and sought to provoke the obscenity trial of the century. Only it didn’t, quietly vanishing instead. Colin Dickey rereads this failed satire, finding a transcendent rhythm pulsing beneath the novel’s indulgent prose.

title: Fantazius’ Folly: Tiny Cryptic #1
content: First instalment in our new series of extremely small and free-form cryptic crossword puzzles, themed on our latest essay.

title: Digital Tribulations 6: Digital Sovereignty and the Political Economy of Latin American Platformization

title: DLCL ATS round-up, winter 2020

title: The Cloud
content: How do you make the invisible visible? This is the central premise of The Cloud, a project that I’ve been working on as a technologist in residence at LIL. The idea originated as a visual joke about the cloud: the vaporous metaphor we use to describe the distributed servers that host remotely-run software and infrastructure.

WARC-GPT allows for creating custom chatbots that use a set of web archive files as their knowledge base, letting users explore collections through conversation.
Using WARC-GPT, you can ask specific que

title: The Cost of a Digital Archive
content: At LIL, we’ve been providing users with the ability to preserve online sources via Perma.cc since 2013. Running a digital archive puts us in the “forever business”–what’s online today may be gone tomorrow, but that Perma Link you saved should never expire. Promising to host something forever brings with it different challenges than hosting something for a month or a year. There are the technical b
creator: Rebecca Kilberg

title: Welcoming Fellow Katy Gero
content: The LIL team is excited to welcome Katy Gero, who joins us to investigate ethical language models for creative writing. Katy is a post-doc at the Variation Lab at Harvard SEAS, which is led by friend of LIL Elena Glassman.

creator: Jack Cushman

title: Conference talk: disruptive innovation in libraries
content:
This piece is adapted from a keynote talk I gave at Innovación y Experiencia del Usuario at Universidad Católica de Argentina on November 1, 2023.
I was asked to give a talk on the subject of “disruptive innovation in libraries,” which isn’t necessarily the phrase I would choose to describe our work, but I enjoyed using that lens to explore the changes all libraries are going through.
If you want
creator: Jack Cushman

title: AI Book Bans: Testing LLMs Against the Freedom to Read
content: What happens when large language models are asked to provide justifications for book bans? Do the same built-in guardrails that prevent them from generating pipe-bomb recipes kick in, or do models do their best to comply with the user’s request? How do models go about providing such justifications while navigating their “knowledge” of library principles? And what could this all mean for the future

title: Mysterious Search Algorithms
content: Lawyers use search algorithms on a daily or even hourly basis, but the way they work often remains mysterious. Users receive pages and pages of results from searches that ostensibly are based on some relevancy standard, seemingly guaranteeing that the most important results are all found. But that may not always be the case. This post explores the mystery of search algorithms from a legal research
creator: William Yao

ChatGPT:

creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

content: There is no one-size-fits-all when it comes to web archiving techniques, and the variety of tools and services available to capture web content illustrate the wide, ever-growing set of needs in the web archiving community. creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

We are excited to announce the release of our “reading mode” - a new casebook view that offers students a cohesive digital format to facilitate deep reading.

to give a webinar on the topic of “Archiving Twitter” on January 12.
During this talk, I presented what we’ve learned building thread-keeper, the experimental open-source software behind social.perma.cc which allows for making high-fidelity captures of twitter.com urls as “sealed” PDFs.

text in response, using the vast quantity of information the models they run were trained on.
Gartner Hype Cycle, ChatGPT and its 
potential amazes and fascinates as much as it bewilders and worries.

creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

ChatGPT to write some

creator: Jack Cushman

The Harvard Library Innovation Lab is delighted to welcome Molly White as an academic fellow.
Molly has become a leading critic on cryptocurrency and web3 issues through her blog Web3 is Going Just Great as well as her long-form research and essays, talks, guest lectures, social media, and interviews. Her rigorous, independent, and accessible work has had a substantial impact on legislators, media
creator: Jack Cushman

The replayweb.page software suite developed by our long-time partner Webrecorder is, to date, the most ad
creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

Trends now supports flexible queries of how cases cite other cases in addition to the other ways in which cases can be filtered. creator: Andy Gu

These new features enable users to easily generate timelines of cases and explore patterns in case citations. We hope that they can help researchers uncover new insights about American caselaw.

didn't stray far from their well-worn model. In many ways, that's a good

creator: Jaromir Savelka, Huihui Xu, Kevin D. Ashley

content:

In-text figures and illustrations in cases. An example, from Sussman v. Cooper (1976), is below.
Inline page numbers. You can provide a pin cite to a specific page in a case by adding #p123 to the URL, or just by clicking the page number.
Italic formatting in case text, as detected by OCR.

content: In the Spring of 2019, at the University of Iowa, I taught an experimental course called Introduction to Quantitative & Computational Legal Reasoning. The course is taught in Python, and focuses on introductory coding and statistics, with focused applications in the law (such as statistical evidence of discrimination).

title: IIPC 2017 – Day Two
content: Most of us attended the technical track on day two of IIPC 2017. (See also Matt’s post about the first day Andrew Jackson of the British Library expanded on his talk the previous day about workflows for ingesting and processing web archives. Nick Ruest and Ian Milligan described WALK, or Web Archiving for Longitudinal Knowledge, a system for aggregating Canadian web archives, generating derivative
creator: Ben Steinberg

title: IIPC 2017 – Day One
content:
It’s exciting to be back at IIPC this year to chat Perma.cc and web archives!
The conference kicked off at on Wednesday, June 14, at 9:00 with coffee, snacks, and familiar faces from all parts of the world. Web archives bring us together physically!
creator: Matt Phillips

title: LIL Talks: The 180-Degree Rule in Film
content: This week, Jack Cushman illustrated how hard it is to make a film, or rather, how easy it is to make a bad film. With the assistance of LIL staff and interns, he directed a tiny film of four lines in about four minutes, then used it as a counter-example. Any mistake can break the suspension of disbelief, and amateurs are likely to make many mistakes. Infelicities in shot selection, lighting, sound
creator: Ben Steinberg

title: LIL Talks: Synthesizer
content: This week Ben Steinberg took us on a strange and magical trip through the world of synthesizers.
creator: Adam Ziegler

title: LIL Talks: Seltzer!
content: In this week’s LIL talk, Matt Phillips gave us an effervescent presentation on Seltzer, followed by a tasting.
creator: Drew (Andy) Silva

content:

creator: Anastasia Aizman

title: LIL Talks: Parsing Caselaw
content: In last week’s LIL talk, expert witness Adam Ziegler took the stand to explain the structure of legal opinions and give an overview of our country’s appellate process.
creator: Drew (Andy) Silva

title: Privacy Concerns vs. Traditions – When the World Changes Around You
content:
(This is a guest post from the amazing Jessamyn West, who we’re lucky to have with us this year as a Research Fellow.)
I live in a town of 4500 people. Like most towns in Vermont we have an annual Town Meeting. We vote by Australian Ballot on things like budgets, but there’s time at the end of the meeting for Other Business. This year we discussed whether Randolph should become a sanctuary town. A
creator: Adam Ziegler

title: LIL Talks: Ania
content: We were fortunate to have Harvard scholar (and LIL friend) Ania Aizman talk to us about Anarchism. She clarified what it was, discussed some of its different branches and how they overlap with familiar groups/events like the Occupy movement.
creator: Brett Johnson

title: LIL Talks: Adam

title: Nuremberg Tribunals Project Launches New Website
content:
The Nuremberg Tribunals Project is excited to announce the launch of its new website.
Our team at the Harvard Library Innovation Lab and the Harvard Law Library’s Department of Historical and Special Collections has been working hard the past year to create a new, rich, flexible and visually appealing discovery and viewing experience for our 750,000-page Nuremberg Trials archive.  The archive mate
creator: Paul Deschner

title: Ars Electronica Highlights 3
content: I’m sharing more highlights from this year’s Ars Electronica Festival. See parts one and two for even more.
creator: Matt Phillips

title: Versioning in the Caselaw Access Project
content: We have a data management dilemma, and we hope that you — data-smart people of the world — can help us out. We need a versioning and change tracking system for around 50 million XML files, and no existing solutions seem to fit.
creator: Drew (Andy) Silva

title: Ars Electronica Highlights 2
content: I’m sharing more highlights from this year’s Ars Electronica Festival. See part one for more highlights.
creator: Matt Phillips

title: Ars Electronica Festival Highlights
content: I’m so insanely happy to be at the 2016 edition of the Ars Electronica Festival. I’ve wanted to attend for a long time and this year things came together. The festival is as good as I expected.
creator: Matt Phillips

title: Private Talking Spaces Progress
content: We’ve been working hard on our Private Talking Spaces effort. Lots of thinking about how to create equity in shared spaces in libraries. Lots of thinking about how to increase focus for folks talking on phones (and maintain the focus of those around them not talking on phones). Lots of thinking about where private talking spaces might be located in libraries. So much thinking!!
creator: Matt Phillips

title: Summer Fellows Share, Join Us
content: LIL fellows are wrapping up their terms this week! Please join us for and learn from our Fellows as they present their research involving ways we can explore and utilize technology to preserve, prepare, and present information for the common good.
creator: Matt Phillips

title: private talking spaces
content: people want to talk on their cell phones when they’re working in the library. let’s accommodate these desires by providing secure and private talking spaces
creator: Matt Phillips

title: Announcing Summer Fellows
content: We’re beyond thrilled to introduce our first cohort of LIL Summer Fellows. The following seven brilliant minds will be working here in the Harvard Law School Library (HLSL) for the next 12 weeks, exploring new pathways in technology, law, and libraries.
creator: Matt Phillips

title: LIL at IIPC: Noticing Reykjavik

title: How We're Freeing the Law, Part 1: Books
content:
Adi Kamdar is a 1L at Harvard Law School and our embedded reporter on the Free the Law project. In this first post, he tracks the progress of a casebook through our scanning process from start to finish.

creator: Adi Kamdar

title: Free the Law Wintersession Sprint
content: TL;DR: We are running a two week data mining sprint from January 4–15, 2016, open to current Harvard students, based on early access to a brand new data set of American caselaw. To apply, send a resume and brief statement of interest to jcushman at law dot harvard dot edu.
